meta.title: Art Vocabulary
meta.description: Complete glossary of artistic techniques, materials, and supports for Certificate of Authenticity

oil.description: Painting technique using pigments mixed with drying oil, typically linseed oil, characterized by long drying times and complex blending possibilities

acrylic.description: Modern painting technique using pigments dispersed in acrylic emulsion, characterized by quick drying and versatility on various surfaces

watercolor.description: Water-based painting technique using transparent diluted pigments, characterized by transparency effects and wet-on-wet technique

tempera.description: Ancient painting technique using pigments bound with egg yolk emulsion, characterized by quick drying and brilliant opaque colors

gouache.description: Opaque painting technique similar to watercolor but with added white, characterized by full coverage and dense velvety colors

encaustic.description: Ancient painting technique using pigments mixed with heated beeswax, characterized by glossy surfaces and great durability

fresco.description: Mural painting technique applying pigments on fresh lime plaster, allowing carbonation and permanent color integration

graphite.description: Drawing technique using graphite leads of varying hardness, characterized by precise tonal gradations and detailed shading

charcoal.description: Drawing technique using vegetable charcoal sticks, characterized by strong contrasts and ability to quickly cover large surfaces

ink.description: Drawing technique using liquid inks applied with pen or brush, characterized by precise lines and tonal washes

coloredPencil.description: Drawing technique using pencils with wax or oil-based colored leads, characterized by saturated colors and chromatic layering

pastel.description: Drawing technique using sticks of pure pigment bound with gum arabic, characterized by intense colors and velvety texture

sprayPainting.description: Urban painting technique using spray cans for rapid color application, characterized by airbrush-like gradients and stencils

mixedMedia.description: Artistic approach combining various techniques and materials in a single work, characterized by experimentation and new expressions

collage.description: Artistic technique assembling various materials (paper, photographs, fabrics) on a support, creating compositions through layering and juxtaposition

assemblage.description: Three-dimensional sculptural technique combining found objects and diverse materials, creating new forms through assemblage of pre-existing elements

etching.description: Intaglio technique incising metal plate with nitric acid through a design traced on protective varnish, creating grooves that hold ink

engraving.description: Direct intaglio technique incising metal plate with burin, creating precise grooves through metal removal with cutting tools

drypoint.description: Intaglio technique directly incising metal plate with steel point, characterized by soft lines and burrs creating velvety effects

mezzotint.description: Intaglio technique creating tones through uniform plate granulation with rocker, allowing continuous tonal gradations from black to white

aquatint.description: Intaglio technique creating tones through etching granulated resin on plate, allowing painterly and atmospheric effects similar to watercolor

lithography.description: Planographic printing technique on limestone using incompatibility between grease and water, allowing soft painterly prints

screenprint.description: Stencil printing technique passing ink through fine mesh fabric, characterized by uniform colors and high edition possibilities

woodcut.description: Relief printing technique carving wood along the grain, removing non-printing areas and leaving design in relief for inking

linocut.description: Relief printing technique carving linoleum instead of wood, characterized by easier carving and more fluid lines

monotype.description: Printing technique producing single impression by painting directly on plate and transferring image to paper, combining painting and printing

carving.description: Subtractive sculptural technique removing material from solid block (stone, wood) to reveal form, characterized by precision and irreversibility

modeling.description: Additive sculptural technique building form by adding and shaping plastic material like clay or wax, characterized by flexibility and correctability

casting.description: Sculptural technique reproducing forms through pouring molten material (bronze, aluminum) into molds, allowing multiple high-quality reproductions

lostWax.description: Ancient casting technique using wax model eliminated during process, allowing creation of complex forms and refined details in metal

welding.description: Modern sculptural technique joining metal elements through local fusion, characterized by industrial constructive and expressive possibilities

print3d.description: Digital sculptural technique building three-dimensional forms layer by layer from digital files, characterized by geometric precision and complex forms

gelatinSilver.description: Analog photographic process using paper sensitized with gelatin and silver salts emulsion, characterized by wide tonal range and archivability

albumen.description: Historical 19th century photographic process using egg albumen to bind silver salts, characterized by glossy surface and refined details

cyanotype.description: Alternative photographic process using iron salts to create images with characteristic Prussian blue color, developed through sun exposure

platinum.description: Noble photographic process using platinum salts to create images of exceptional stability and tonal range, characterized by secular durability

chromogenic.description: Color photographic process forming image through organic dyes during development, used for modern color prints

inkjet.description: Digital printing process depositing microscopic ink drops on paper, characterized by high resolution and precise color control

digitalPrint.description: Computerized printing process transferring digital images to physical supports through professional high-resolution printers

generative.description: Artistic practice using algorithms and autonomous systems to generate works, characterized by use of computer code as creative tool

render3d.description: Digital process generating two-dimensional images from computerized three-dimensional models, using lighting, materials, and perspective calculations

videoSingleChannel.description: Artistic video format using single video stream played on monitor or projection, basic form of contemporary video art

installationInteractive.description: Artwork responding to audience interaction through sensors, digital technologies, or physical mechanisms, creating participatory experiences

arVr.description: Immersive technologies overlaying digital elements on real world (AR) or creating completely virtual environments (VR) for interactive artistic experiences

weaving.description: Technique interlacing warp and weft threads to create fabrics, using mechanical or manual looms for artistic and functional structures

embroidery.description: Decorative technique applying colored threads on base fabric through specific stitches, creating ornamental and three-dimensional pictorial motifs

tapestry.description: Artistic weaving technique creating figurative images through interlacing colored threads, traditionally executed on high-warp loom

felting.description: Technique compacting animal fibers (wool) through moisture, heat, and pressure, creating resilient and versatile non-woven fabric

batik.description: Resist-dyeing technique using hot wax to protect parts of fabric from dye, creating patterns through successive immersions

shibori.description: Japanese resist-dyeing technique using ties, folds, and compressions to create patterns through selective color resistance

knitting.description: Textile construction technique interlacing yarn loops through knitting needles, creating elastic fabrics and three-dimensional structures

crochet.description: Textile construction technique using single hook to create structures through concatenated yarn loops, allowing irregular shapes

wheelThrown.description: Ceramic technique shaping clay on rotating wheel, characterized by symmetrical forms and uniform walls through centering and lifting

handbuilt.description: Ceramic technique building forms without wheel using coils, slabs, or direct modeling, allowing asymmetrical and expressive forms

slipCast.description: Industrial ceramic technique pouring liquid clay into porous plaster molds, allowing identical reproductions and complex hollow forms

raku.description: Japanese ceramic technique extracting incandescent work from kiln and reducing in combustible materials, creating unique chromatic effects

blown.description: Glassmaking technique shaping molten glass through air insufflation, using blowpipe to create hollow and organic forms

kilnformed.description: Glassmaking technique shaping glass through controlled kiln heating, allowing fusions, slumping, and mold forming

lampworking.description: Glassmaking technique shaping glass rods through torch flame, characterized by precision and miniaturistic detail possibilities

stained.description: Architectural glassmaking technique assembling colored glass with lead joints, creating figurative compositions for natural lighting

fabrication.description: Complete jewelry creation process including design, metalworking, setting, and finishing for artisanal or industrial production

forging.description: Metalworking technique modifying forms through plastic deformation with hammers, characterized by structural consolidation and surface textures

filigree.description: Ornamental technique interweaving thin metal wires to create openwork patterns, characterized by lightness and decorative complexity

settingBezel.description: Setting technique completely surrounding gem with metal, characterized by maximum protection and clean lines

settingProng.description: Setting technique holding gem with small metal claws, maximizing light penetration into stone

enamelCloisonne.description: Enameling technique using metal wires to create compartments filled with colored enamels, typical of Byzantine and Oriental art

oil.description: Pigments dispersed in drying oil (linseed, poppy, walnut), characterized by slow drying, high chromatic saturation, and complex blending possibilities

acrylic.description: Pigments dispersed in acrylic polymer emulsion, characterized by quick drying, water resistance once dry, and application versatility

watercolor.description: Finely ground pigments bound with gum arabic, characterized by transparency, water solubility, and chromatic layering effects

bronze.description: Copper and tin alloy (88%-12%), characterized by durability, corrosion resistance, and natural blue-green patina over time

gold.description: Noble metal characterized by inalterability, extreme malleability, and purity measured in carats (24kt = pure gold), used in jewelry and sacred art

silver.description: Silver alloy at 92.5% with copper, international jewelry standard, characterized by greater hardness than pure silver and optimal workability

diamond.description: Pure carbon crystal, the hardest natural substance (hardness 10 Mohs), characterized by exceptional dispersion and incomparable brilliance

ruby.description: Red variety of corundum, characterized by intense red color from chromium, 9 Mohs hardness, and use in high-end jewelry

sapphire.description: Non-red variety of corundum, characterized by various colors (classic blue), 9 Mohs hardness, and gemological prestige

emerald.description: Green variety of beryl, characterized by intense color from chromium or vanadium, traditionally associated with royalty and wisdom

cotton.description: Cotton fiber textile support prepared with primer, characterized by uniform weave, moderate elasticity, and standard use for oil and acrylic painting

linen.description: Premium linen fiber textile support, characterized by superior resistance, excellent dimensional stability, and fine surface for conservation works

wood.description: Rigid support in solid or multi-layer wood prepared, characterized by dimensional stability, uniform surface, and classical painting tradition

mdf.description: Medium Density Fiberboard, economical support characterized by perfectly smooth surface, no grain, and easy preparation

watercolor.description: Paper support specific for water techniques, characterized by controlled absorption, moisture resistance, and appropriate texture for watercolor

drawing.description: Universal paper support for drawing, characterized by smooth or slightly textured surface, medium weight, and versatility for various dry techniques
